DataElement.preferredName: Neoadjuvant Therapy Fluorouracil Administered Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The yes/no indicator related to the administration of fluorouracil in a neoadjuvant setting.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to the administration of fluorouracil in a neoadjuvant setting.  Fluorouracil is an antimetabolite fluoropyrimidine analog of the nucleoside pyrimidine with antineoplastic activity.  Fluorouracil and its metabolites possess a number of different mechanisms of action.  In vivo, fluoruracil is converted to the active metabolite 5-fluoroxyuridine monophosphate (F-UMP); replacing uracil, F-UMP incorporates into RNA and inhibits RNA processing, thereby inhibiting cell growth.  Another active metabolite, 5-5-fluoro-2'-deoxyuridine-5'-O-monophosphate (F-dUMP), inhibits thymidylate synthase, resulting in the depletion of thymidine triphosphate (TTP), a necessary constituent of DNA.  Other fluorouracil metabolites incorporate into both RNA and DNA; incorporation into RNA results in major effects on both the processing and functions of RNA.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Treatment designed to be used as a first step toward shrinking the cancer and in evaluating response to drugs and other agents. Induction therapy is followed by additional therapy to eliminate whatever cancer remains.

Concepts.definition: Therapy administered prior to the primary treatment for the purpose of making the primary treatment more effective.

Property.preferredDefinition: An antimetabolite fluoropyrimidine analog of the nucleoside pyrimidine with antineoplastic activity.  Fluorouracil and its metabolites possess a number of different mechanisms of action.  In vivo, fluoruracil is converted to the active metabolite 5-fluoroxyuridine monophosphate (F-UMP); replacing uracil, F-UMP incorporates into RNA and inhibits RNA processing, thereby inhibiting cell growth.  Another active metabolite, 5-5-fluoro-2'-deoxyuridine-5'-O-monophosphate (F-dUMP), inhibits thymidylate synthase, resulting in the depletion of thymidine triphosphate (TTP), a necessary constituent of DNA.  Other fluorouracil metabolites incorporate into both RNA and DNA; incorporation into RNA results in major effects on both the processing and functions of RNA. (NCI04):The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

Concepts.definition: An antimetabolite fluoropyrimidine analog of the nucleoside pyrimidine with antineoplastic activity. Fluorouracil and its metabolites possess a number of different mechanisms of action. In vivo, fluoruracil is converted to the active metabolite 5-fluoroxyuridine monophosphate (F-UMP); replacing uracil, F-UMP incorporates into RNA and inhibits RNA processing, thereby inhibiting cell growth. Another active metabolite, 5-5-fluoro-2'-deoxyuridine-5'-O-monophosphate (F-dUMP), inhibits thymidylate synthase, resulting in the depletion of thymidine triphosphate (TTP), one of the four nucleotide triphosphates used in the in vivo synthesis of DNA. Other fluorouracil metabolites incorporate into both RNA and DNA; incorporation into RNA results in major effects on both RNA processing and functions.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).
